sect1.title: The Freedom Toaster
sect1.para: It was just over a decade ago when Netscape floated and brought the World Wide Web into the office, classroom and home, changing us from passive consumers of information, to active participators.

Societies and economies have boomed due to the sharing of information. Both business and learning have found commercial and cultural communities to interact with – instantly. Knowledge has always driven the ability to attain and maintain wealth, in the 21st century this has never been more real.

Whilst the Internet has been hailed as a "great equalizer" (Brynjolfsson and Smith 2000) of developing and developed nations there are however, "great disparities in opportunity to access the Internet, the information and the educational/business opportunities tied to this" (wikipedia.org, 07.10.05).

Due to poor quality and costly infrastructures, the knowledge gap, and all that that implies, is widening. This knowledge gap is not just prevalent between developed and developing countries, but is also seen in poor rural areas of the Western world. This is inhibiting education, commerce and good health practice for all.
The Freedom Toaster acts as an equaliser.

entry.para: The Freedom Toaster is both a concept and a physical machine. As a concept, the Freedom Toaster is a bandwidth substitute. It is a way of moving massive amounts of information from a variety of sources, including the Internet, to the remote end user without the infrastructure that is usually required. Currently it is a system for disseminating Free and Open Source Software (FOSS) and content (operating systems, productivity and business software, community e-books, e-learning packages). In physical form the Freedom Toaster is a low cost computer, with CD/DVD-burning devices and a web browser enabled touch screen interface assembled into what looks like a vending machine.

The name "Freedom Toaster" was chosen because it uses Linux, a free license Operating System, and within the language of Linux users the act of burning a CD is termed "toasting". However, it later became apparent that the name had a deeper meaning than originally intended. It encapsulates the philosophy of FOSS. We have the freedom to choose which software we use, we have the freedom to change it if we want to, and we have the freedom to share it with anyone, for free.

The Shuttleworth Foundation created and invested in the Freedom Toaster project to further its mandate of driving innovation. Mark Shuttleworth, the foundations' founder, believes that "if we are to lift Africa from her current circumstances, we will need a generation of learners that are gifted with curiosity about the world in which they live, and the tools to understand and shape that world".
To do this, they need access to information.

sect1.title: The importance of the Freedom Toaster
sect1.para: The situation - In many parts of the world, particularly in the developing world, there is a lack of communication infrastructure and access to high technology. Whilst many in the developed world are able to use the Internet to communicate in education, business and recreation, this is not the case in regions such as Africa, South America, or Asia. The Internet World Stats Report (23rd July 2005) states that in Africa only 1.8% of the population are Internet users. In Latin America/Caribbean the figure is 12.5% and Asia is 8.9%. It is evident that these populations do not benefit from the advantages that the Internet can give. Even if there is access, it is often costly, of low bandwidth and quality. This prevents downloading of the type of software and content that is available on the Freedom Toaster.

The difference - now - Like many new concepts it is important to understand the need that inspired the Freedom Toaster. It is equally important to understand how the concept has developed, and what the possibilities may be, both now and in the future. Freedom Toasters are currently available in sub-Saharan Africa and although the number of Freedom Toaster's is only in double digits and the system is still in its infancy, we can see the real difference in people's lives.

Through the hosting of Freedom Toasters, FOSS and content is made available to everyone, regardless of colour, race, creed, religion, sexual orientation, class, economic background, or political affiliation.

The Internet user who does not have the bandwidth to download a full operating system to use on their computer can now go to a Freedom Toaster and burn one of the 13 different distributions of Linux currently available. This frees the person from the frustration and cost of spending hours online waiting for a download (that may be corrupted due to poor local connectivity) and then burning the CDs. It also saves the countries limited bandwidth from continued downloads of the same files.

The person who has no access to the Internet but has a computer can now burn an operating system, the OpenOffice.org productivity suite (immediately benefiting from the word processor and spreadsheet applications), or the Project Gutenberg CD/DVD and utilise them at no extra cost.

The Teachers can use the material on the Freedom Toaster to learn content for themselves, and then teach what they have learnt. This could be the prefect distribution tool for Departments of Education - ensuring that all teachers have curriculum aligned materials to teach from.

A computer user who has used pirated software can erase all of all their illegal software and install an up-to-date operating system that will provide all the necessary tools they need to accomplish their computing tasks.

If an entrepreneur wishes to make money from their computer, by running an import-export business, an accountancy practise, or a printing works, they are going to need software specifically designed for the task. This doesn't come cheap. There is FOSS software that fulfils all the criteria, available on the Internet, but these packages are large, even by broadband standards, and not much good to someone who hasn't even got a phone. With access to the Freedom Toaster the business person now has access to this software, just for the price of the blank CDs.

General computer knowledge is increased by having Freedom Toasters in public places (libraries, community centres, science/technology centres). For many people, computer literacy is one of the key knowledge areas needed to find a better job. The Freedom Toaster provides access to FOSS operating systems and productivity software that can be used to train people how to use a computer, how to type, and how to write documents, spreadsheets, and other documents. Computer literacy is improved, and more of the digital divide is crossed.

The difference - future - It is difficult to know what will happen in the future, but there are specific trends that can be traced, and predictions made. We can also imagine what the future will hold by asking ourselves where we would want the world to be, and what would be different if a project such as the Freedom Toaster proliferated across the developing world.

Gartner, a world renowned technology/business analysis and research company, in their report entitled 'Gartners' Positions on the Five Hottest IT Topics and Trends in 2005', tells us that Open Source Software (OSS) (a subset of FOSS) is a catalyst that will restructure the IT industry, producing higher-quality software at a lower cost. They predict that it won't destroy industry giants, such as IBM and Microsoft, but that it will revolutionise software markets by moving revenue streams from license fees to services and support.

Gartner warns that OSS strategies must address the unique characteristics of individual markets and the differences in open-source license models. The Freedom Toaster is one way of addressing OSS strategy within markets that have low (or no) Internet penetration. The report by Gartner states that "through 2005, OSS products will account for no more than 10 percent of the portfolio of Global 2000 companies, but by 2008, 95 percent of Global 2000 organisations will have formal open-source acquisition and management strategies that address the challenges and opportunities that OSS introduces". If that many Global 2000 organisations will be involved at some level, then access to FOSS will bring greater involvement in the global economy and will create real opportunities for disadvantaged communities.

In 10 years time the world of computer software will be a completely different place. Through projects like the Freedom Toaster, people could have access to FOSS and choose this instead of piracy. Computer software companies could be making their profits from offering technical support for FOSS projects and services instead of licenses for operating systems and proprietary programs - opening up the market for small businesses and aiding economic growth in rural developing nations.

In 15 years time the influence of FOSS may have changed the technical inequalities of the developed and developing worlds. This means that the high school student in SOWETO could customise an email system as part of a school project. When she graduates from high school she could go on to become a high powered programmer for a major corporation or enterprise. Or a student in Bogotá, learning an accountancy package can take the software with him when leaving school and set up his own business.

Having easy access to free license software could change so many people's lives for the better. Teachers can have content, businesses can keep their books, entertainers, programmers, musicians, writers, journalists, students, governments, multimedia producers, and even cooks and cleaners could live better lives because of the influence of something as simple as a Freedom Toaster.

sect1.title: What is the role of the Freedom Toaster in context of global development efforts?
sect1.para: The Freedom Toaster is a simple solution to a seemingly impossible problem - access. By enabling access, we can help lift the barrier to educational content and start to create a level playing field for the developing world.

para.emphasis: Access to information as a human right

listitem.para: One of the fundamental principles that the Freedom Toaster addresses is the idea that access to information is a basic human right. In many places around the world information is inaccessible. The Freedom Toaster project creates a vehicle for improving that access. It provides a platform for distributing information and software to allow you to use and learn from it.

Access to the texts of the Project Gutenberg, and to other distributable content (like awareness programs, community educational material and general reference data on wikipedia.org) will enable teachers to better educate children and communities, resulting in greater opportunities to prosper.

This better educated community will also enable small and medium sized businesses to run with lower start-up and operating costs by using the FOSS provided on the Freedom Toaster. Access to the source code will mean greater customisation to local conditions by local programmers, ensuring that businesses can be efficient, flexible and get the best from their tools.

The 'digital divide' is a key development issue. The Freedom Toaster provides a vehicle for accessing FOSS where there is low or no Internet access, and this brings digital information that requires high-bandwidth to a low digital penetration area.

The ability to access information is relatively high in the developed world - compulsive schooling, public libraries, media. The developing world is not able to compete on this scale, either in terms of education or business. Virtual classrooms are not an option for most in these regions, but virtual classroom information could be made available through the vehicle of a Freedom Toaster.

The use of the software distributed by the Freedom Toaster will also create markets and demand. Once more people are computer literate there will be a greater demand for better communications infrastructure, and an increased demand for other basic community needs.
The Freedom Toaster can be used as a tool to provide a means of empowerment. Knowledge brings empowerment, and so access to knowledge brings the potential of empowerment.

Women in Kabul would potentially have the same access and empowerment opportunities as those in London. Men in Chile would have similar access and opportunities to benefit from the open source movement as someone in the United States or Europe.

Children in Sucre, Bolivia or in the disadvantaged northern inner-city areas of the United Kingdom can have the same educational resources as Perth, Australia. The potential of increased and equal access to FOSS, tutorials, encyclopedias, and other reference materials (like the US CIA World Fact Book contained in the Project Gutenberg and all of the collaborative content provided on wikipedia.org) will bring higher quality education and greater empowerment for teachers as well as students.

High quality operating systems and business productivity software (both office and Internet) are the virtual infrastructure of the information age - something that is denied in areas of no real infrastructure. The Freedom Toaster instantaneously solves this problem.

The potential infrastructure provided by access to a Freedom Toaster goes beyond the software that it distributes. The general educational value and computer literacy increase is a vital part of the virtual infrastructure; ensuring that people are not left behind due to their geographic location.

para.emphasis: Free and Legal vs. Culture of Piracy

listitem.para: The Freedom Toaster addresses the issue of piracy by providing a high quality alternative. According to the Software Piracy Study done by the Business Software Association of Australia in 2004, an estimated 86% of software installed on the computers in Zimbabwe was pirated. In India the figure was at 73%, in Brazil 61%, in South Africa 36%.

For every two dollars worth of software purchased legitimately, one dollar worth is obtained illegally. In economic terms, this costs a country local business and revenue, and increases costs of policing and policy creation.

With FOSS there is no need for a culture of piracy. The operating systems use free licenses. Within the open source arena people can also access the code and develop it to suit their own needs, or develop it in cooperation with others.

Literacy is the passport for full participation in today's society. Anyone who cannot read or write will face difficulties in finding work, managing their health, raising children, and coping with simple, every-day tasks such as shopping and paying bills. Illiterate adults are often excluded from political and social processes, and as such, are denied the chance to exercise their rights and fulfil their responsibilities as citizens. Yet nearly one seventh of the world's population is illiterate.
Worldwide figures released by UNESCO in August 2005 indicate that 784.8 million adults over the age of 15 cannot read or write. Even more alarming is that just under two thirds are women.
Educational aptitude and abilities rise with the proliferation of information - improving literacy problems in the developing world.

sect1.para: The concepts contained in the Freedom Toaster project and the software that it distributes help tackle many of the problems faced by the developing world, and even some faced in the developed world.

sect1.title: Implementation
sect1.para: The Shuttleworth Foundation has provided the resources to take the idea of the Freedom Toaster and make it a reality. Now the project needs to go where it is really needed - the rest of the world.

The first stage is educating people about the Freedom Toaster concept. Community project directors, Head Librarian's, Science Centre committees, and other organisations and leaders are being approached with the possibility of hosting a Freedom Toaster.

The Shuttleworth Foundation drives social innovation by piloting projects and then establishing information channels that explain successes and promote replication. By giving people the tools to create, implement, maintain, market and develop Freedom Toasters it is hoped that the project will grow wings and help disadvantaged communities in all four corners of the world.

sect2.title: Where?
sect2.para: The list of where to host a Freedom Toaster should almost be endless, in South Africa they are based in:

listitem.para: A school that hosts a Freedom Toaster will have access to the latest educational material. With access to the FOSS content the interest of students at the school would also become more highly focused on Information Technology and all the advantages that brings - both in the classroom and later on in life.

The Freedom Toaster currently contains both Project Gutenberg and wikipedia.org. This collection of text based files contains literature from around the world. It is a collection of fact and fiction, high literature (poetry, plays, operas), scientific texts (Darwin's 'Origin of the Species' or Einstein's works on relativity), philosophy, religious texts, and reference works. Having this project available in libraries will increase exposure to world class literature and will increase learning and education for those who are wanting to learn.
The only limit to the information available is copyright law – anything else a library would want can be hosted.
A library will also receive a public service benefit by hosting a Freedom Toaster. The members of the library will gain access to world class software and information.

One of the goals of science centres is to engage the minds of those who visit them with science and technology. Hosting a Freedom Toaster provides a discussion point for the computer science topic and FOSS principles. It also provides a community focus in that people have free access to the operating systems and other software available around from the world.
Increased and prolonged footfall in shopping malls is attained furthering their business directive.

sect2.para: The importance of hosting a Freedom Toaster is not just the benefit that the hosting location receives, but more particularly the benefit to the community. The key is access. Everyone must be able to access the Freedom Toaster, free of charge within reasonable hours in order to burn what they require from it.

sect2.title: When?
sect2.para: The needs and problems that the Freedom Toaster addresses are needs and problems that require an immediate response. There is no other answer to the question of when to implement than 'now!'. People can have access to the FOSS and content distributed by the Freedom Toaster, it is their right.

There are over 2 billion young people alive in the world today, most of them in developing countries, and they are demanding access to the technological wonders of our age. While the Freedom Toaster project does not directly address the problem of getting computers into impoverished and low Internet access communities, it does address the problem of access to the information that the Internet brings. If projects like this are not implemented soon, many of these young people will be disadvantaged and will seek other means of engagement in the information age.

sect2.title: How?
sect2.para: The Shuttleworth Foundation is creating documentation of how to build a Freedom Toaster - The Freedom Toaster CookBook. The CookBook describes in detail each phase of putting the Freedom Toaster together and loading the required software. This information is freely available to anyone and will be ready for use from March 2006. The idea of the Freedom Toaster can be adapted to many other circumstances by using the basic construction information contained in this document.

An educational campaign is also taking place, first for people and institutions to host Freedom Toasters, then for people who will have access to a Freedom Toaster. Computer User Groups and volunteers have been part of this process to date, but more needs to happen if the full benefits of the Freedom Toaster concept are to be realised. Leaders and champions within communities then need to have the Freedom Toaster built and securely placed in the hosting locations.

sect1.title: Future of the Toaster
sect1.para: We believe that we can prevent economic status from being the deciding factor in access to information.

We want to see Freedom Toasters helping to set up businesses in Kinshasa, giving university students' vital thesis content in Oslo and allowing teachers to get scientific reference material in Santiago. The Freedom Toaster is a community based and enabled project and therefore the future of the toaster has to belong to the future of communities - the world.

sect1.para: For more information on where you can find a Freedom Toaster, joining the Freedom Toaster community or building one of your own, please visit: www.freedomtoaster.org or contact info@freedomtoaster.org.
